cards.title: Problem
cards.back: Why not connect peripherals directly to system bus?

cards.title: Reasons
cards.back:
1. **Wide Variety of Peripherals:**
2. Different methods of operation
3. Different data formats
4. Different speeds
5. **Impractical** to incorporate control logic within processor
6. **Speed Mismatch:**
7. **Peripherals often slower** than memory/processor
8. Impractical to use high-speed system bus directly
9. Would waste bus bandwidth
10. **Some Peripherals Faster:**
11. Some devices faster than memory/processor
12. Mismatch leads to inefficiencies if not managed
13. **Data Format Differences:**
14. Peripherals use different data formats
15. Different word lengths
16. Need conversion/translation

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: **I/O Module** required to interface between processor/memory and peripherals.

cards.title: Two Major Functions
cards.back:
1. **Interface to Processor and Memory:**
2. Via system bus or central switch
3. Handles communication with CPU
4. Manages data transfer to/from memory
5. **Interface to Peripheral Devices:**
6. Via data links
7. Handles device-specific protocols
8. Manages device control and status

cards.title: Result
cards.back: I/O module acts as **translator** and **buffer** between system and peripherals.

cards.title: Components
cards.back:
1. **Address Lines:** Identify I/O module and device
2. **Data Lines:** Transfer data
3. **Control Lines:** Control and timing signals
4. **Links to Peripheral Devices:** Device-specific interfaces

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Coordinate flow of traffic between internal resources and external devices.

cards.title: Responsibilities
cards.back:
1. Coordinate processor and I/O module interactions
2. Manage shared resources (bus, memory)
3. Handle timing of operations

cards.title: Example Sequence
cards.back:
1. Processor interrogates I/O module (check device status)
2. I/O module returns device status
3. If device ready, processor requests data transfer
4. I/O module obtains data from external device
5. Data transferred from I/O module to processor

cards.title: Bus Arbitration
cards.back:
1. Each interaction may involve bus arbitration
2. Multiple devices competing for bus access
3. I/O module must coordinate with bus controller

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Enable communication between processor and I/O module.

cards.title: Command Decoding
cards.back:
1. I/O module accepts commands from processor
2. Commands sent as signals on control bus
3. Example: Disk drive commands (READ SECTOR, WRITE SECTOR, SEEK)

cards.title: Data Exchange
cards.back:
1. Data exchanged over data bus
2. Bidirectional communication
3. Handles data format conversion

cards.title: Status Reporting
cards.back:
1. **Critical:** Peripherals are slow
2. I/O module reports status to processor
3. Common status signals:
4. **BUSY:** Module working on previous command
5. **READY:** Module ready for new command
6. Processor can check status before proceeding

cards.title: Address Recognition
cards.back:
1. Each I/O device has unique address
2. I/O module recognizes address for its peripherals
3. Similar to memory addressing

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Enable communication between I/O module and external device.

cards.title: Components
cards.back:
1. **Commands:** I/O module sends commands to device
2. **Status Information:** Device reports status to I/O module
3. **Data:** Actual data transfer

cards.title: Device-Specific
cards.back:
1. Each device type has different protocol
2. I/O module handles device-specific communication
3. Abstracts device details from processor

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Balance speed differences between device and memory.

cards.title: Problem
cards.back:
1. **Memory/Processor:** Very high transfer rates
2. **Peripherals:** Often much slower (orders of magnitude)

cards.title: From Memory to Device
cards.back:
1. Data sent from memory in rapid burst
2. **Buffered in I/O module**
3. Sent to device at device's slower rate

cards.title: From Device to Memory
cards.back:
1. Data received from device slowly
2. **Buffered in I/O module**
3. Prevents tying up memory in slow transfer
4. Can accumulate data before transferring to memory

cards.title: Speed Matching
cards.back:
1. I/O module must operate at **both** device and memory speeds
2. Handles speed conversion
3. Prevents bottlenecks

cards.title: Fast Devices
cards.back:
1. Some devices faster than memory
2. I/O module buffers to prevent memory bottleneck
3. Manages high-speed data streams

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Detect and report errors to processor.

cards.title: 1. Mechanical/Electrical Malfunctions
cards.back:
1. Reported by device itself
2. Examples:
3. Paper jam (printer)
4. Bad disk track
5. Device failure

cards.title: 2. Transmission Errors
cards.back:
1. Unintentional changes to bit pattern
2. During transmission from device to I/O module
3. Need error detection codes

cards.title: Parity Bit
cards.back:
1. Simple example: Parity bit on each character
2. Example: IRA character code (7 bits) + 1 parity bit
3. **Even parity:** Total number of 1s is even
4. **Odd parity:** Total number of 1s is odd
5. I/O module checks parity on receipt
6. Detects single-bit errors

cards.title: More Advanced
cards.back:
1. CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check)
2. Checksums
3. Error-correcting codes

cards.title: Internal Structure
cards.back: Interface to System Bus: ├── Address Lines ├── Data Lines └── Control Lines I/O Module: ├── Data Registers ├── Status/Control Registers ├── I/O Logic │ ├── Address Recognition │ ├── Command Decoding │ └── Status Reporting └── Device Interface Logic Interface to External Device: ├── Data Lines ├── Status Lines └── Control Lines

cards.title: Registers
cards.back:
1. **Data Registers:** Hold data being transferred
2. **Status/Control Registers:** Device status and control information

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: Provide means of exchanging data between external environment and computer.

cards.title: Connection
cards.back: Attached to computer by link to I/O module.

cards.title: Link Purpose
cards.back: Exchange control, status, and data between I/O module and external device.

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Suitable for communicating with computer user.

cards.title: Examples
cards.back:
1. **Video display terminals:** Monitors, screens
2. **Printers:** Output devices
3. **Keyboards:** Input devices
4. **Mice:** Input devices

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. Designed for human interaction
2. Text, graphics, audio output
3. Human-readable input

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Suitable for communicating with equipment.

cards.title: Examples
cards.back:
1. **Magnetic disk and tape systems:** Storage devices
2. **Sensors:** Environmental sensors, temperature, pressure
3. **Actuators:** Motors, valves, switches

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. Designed for machine-to-machine communication
2. Binary data formats
3. Automated operation

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Suitable for communicating with remote devices.

cards.title: Examples
cards.back:
1. **Terminals:** Remote terminals
2. **Machine readable devices:** Remote equipment
3. **Other computers:** Network communication

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. Network connectivity
2. Remote access
3. Protocol-based communication

cards.title: Components
cards.back:
1. **Transducer:**
2. Converts between physical world and electrical signals
3. Input: Physical → Electrical
4. Output: Electrical → Physical
5. **Buffer:**
6. Temporary storage
7. Holds data during transfer
8. Speed matching
9. **Control Logic:**
10. Device control functions
11. Interprets control signals
12. Manages device operation

cards.title: Signals
cards.back:
1. **Control signals from I/O module:** Determine device function
2. **Status signals to I/O module:** Indicate device state
3. **Data bits:** To and from I/O module
4. **Data to/from environment:** Device-specific data

cards.title: Classification
cards.back:
1. **Programmed I/O**
2. No interrupts
3. I/O-to-memory transfer through processor
4. **Interrupt-Driven I/O**
5. Use of interrupts
6. I/O-to-memory transfer through processor
7. **Direct Memory Access (DMA)**
8. Use of interrupts
9. Direct I/O-to-memory transfer

cards.title: Key Difference
cards.back: Role of processor in data transfer.

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: Processor directly controls I/O operation.

cards.title: Process
cards.back:
1. Processor executes I/O instruction
2. Issues command to I/O module
3. I/O module performs action
4. Sets status bits in status register
5. **Processor must periodically check status**
6. Processor waits until operation complete

cards.title: Key Characteristic
cards.back: **I/O module does NOT interrupt processor.**

cards.title: Processor Responsibility
cards.back:
1. Must check status repeatedly
2. Waits for I/O completion
3. Cannot do other work while waiting

cards.title: Four Types of I/O Commands
cards.back:
1. **Control:**
2. Activate peripheral
3. Tell device what to do
4. Example: Start printer, seek disk track
5. **Test:**
6. Test status conditions
7. Check I/O module and peripheral status
8. Example: Check if device ready, check for errors
9. **Read:**
10. I/O module obtains data from peripheral
11. Places data in internal buffer
12. Processor reads from buffer
13. **Write:**
14. I/O module takes data from data bus
15. Transmits data to peripheral
16. Processor writes to I/O module

cards.title: Input of Block of Data
cards.back:
1. Issue Read command to I/O module
2. Read status of I/O module
3. Check if ready
4. If not ready: Loop back to step 2
5. If ready: Continue
6. Read word from I/O module
7. Write word into memory
8. Check if done
9. If not done: Go to step 1 (next word)
10. If done: Next instruction

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **CPU waits:** Processor tied up during I/O
2. **Polling:** Must check status repeatedly
3. **Inefficient:** Wastes processor time
4. **Simple:** Easy to implement

cards.title: Drawbacks
cards.back:
1. Processor cannot do other work
2. Wastes CPU cycles checking status
3. Slow for slow devices

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: I/O module interrupts processor when ready.

cards.title: Process
cards.back:
1. Processor issues I/O command
2. **Processor continues executing other instructions**
3. I/O module works on I/O operation
4. When ready, I/O module **interrupts processor**
5. Processor handles interrupt
6. Executes data transfer
7. Resumes former processing

cards.title: Key Advantage
cards.back: **Processor can do other work while waiting.**

cards.title: Input of Block of Data
cards.back:
1. Issue Read command to I/O module
2. Do something else (other instructions)
3. Interrupt occurs (I/O module ready)
4. Read status of I/O module
5. Check for error condition
6. Read word from I/O module
7. Write word into memory
8. Check if done
9. If not done: Go to step 1
10. If done: Return to interrupted program

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **CPU not waiting:** Can do other work
2. **Asynchronous:** I/O happens in background
3. **Efficient:** Better CPU utilization
4. **More complex:** Requires interrupt handling

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. Better CPU utilization
2. Can handle multiple I/O operations
3. More responsive system

cards.title: Drawbacks
cards.back:
1. Still involves processor in each transfer
2. Interrupt overhead
3. More complex than programmed I/O

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: I/O module and memory exchange data directly without processor involvement.

cards.title: Process
cards.back:
1. Processor issues block read command to DMA module
2. **Processor continues executing other instructions**
3. DMA module transfers entire block directly to/from memory
4. DMA module interrupts processor when complete

cards.title: Key Advantage
cards.back: **Processor only involved at start and end.**

cards.title: Input of Block of Data
cards.back:
1. Issue Read block command to DMA module
2. Do something else (other instructions)
3. DMA transfers data directly to memory
4. Interrupt occurs (DMA complete)
5. Read status of DMA module
6. Check for error condition
7. Next instruction

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **Minimal CPU involvement:** Only at start and end
2. **Direct transfer:** I/O to memory, bypassing CPU
3. **Very efficient:** Best for large transfers
4. **Most complex:** Requires DMA controller

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **Maximum efficiency:** CPU free during transfer
2. **High throughput:** Can transfer large blocks
3. **Best for bulk data:** Disk, network transfers

cards.title: Drawbacks
cards.back:
1. Most complex implementation
2. Requires DMA controller hardware
3. Bus arbitration needed

cards.title: Evolution
cards.back: Programmed → Interrupt-Driven → DMA (increasing efficiency and complexity)

cards.title: Question
cards.back: How does processor identify I/O devices?

cards.title: Answer
cards.back: Two modes of addressing when processor, memory, and I/O share common bus.

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: I/O devices and memory locations share **single address space**.

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. I/O looks just like memory read/write
2. **No special commands** for I/O
3. Processor uses **same machine instructions** for memory and I/O
4. Status and data registers treated as memory locations

cards.title: Address Space
cards.back:
1. Combined total of memory and I/O addresses
2. Example: 10 address lines → 2^10 = 1024 locations
3. Can be any combination (e.g., 512 memory + 512 I/O)

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **Large selection of memory access commands available**
2. Can use all memory instructions (load, store, arithmetic)
3. Simpler instruction set
4. Flexible addressing

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **Reduces memory address space**
2. Memory and I/O compete for addresses
3. Need to reserve address space for I/O

cards.title: Example
cards.back: Address 516: Keyboard input data register Address 517: Keyboard input status register Load AC, 517 ; Get status Branch if Sign = 0, 202 ; Loop until ready Load AC, 516 ; Load data byte

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: **Separate address spaces** for memory and I/O.

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. Need **I/O or memory select lines** on bus
2. **Special commands** for I/O (IN, OUT, Test I/O)
3. Limited set of I/O instructions
4. I/O addresses separate from memory addresses

cards.title: Address Space
cards.back:
1. Memory: Full address space (e.g., 1024 locations)
2. I/O: Separate address space (e.g., 1024 I/O ports)
3. **Total:** More addressable locations

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **Full memory address space** available
2. Memory and I/O don't compete
3. Clear separation

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **Limited set of I/O instructions**
2. Special instructions needed
3. Less flexible than memory-mapped

cards.title: Example
cards.back: Load I/O, 5 ; Initiate keyboard read Test I/O, 5 ; Check for completion Branch Not Ready, 201 ; Loop until complete In, 5 ; Load data byte

cards.title: Modern Practice
cards.back: Most systems use **memory-mapped I/O** for flexibility.

cards.title: Problem with Programmed I/O
cards.back:
1. Processor must wait long time for I/O module
2. Wastes processor time
3. Inefficient

cards.title: Solution
cards.back:
1. Processor issues I/O command
2. Goes on to do other useful work
3. I/O module interrupts when ready
4. Processor handles transfer and resumes

cards.title: Hardware Steps
cards.back:
1. Device controller issues interrupt
2. Processor finishes current instruction
3. Processor signals acknowledgment
4. Processor pushes PSW and PC onto control stack

cards.title: Software Steps
cards.back:
1. Save remainder of process state information
2. Process interrupt
3. Restore process state information
4. Restore old PSW and PC

cards.title: Result
cards.back: Processor loads new PC value based on interrupt, executes interrupt service routine, then returns.

cards.title: Before Interrupt
cards.back:
1. Program Counter: N
2. Stack Pointer: T
3. General Registers: Various values
4. User's Program executing

cards.title: After Interrupt
cards.back:
1. Program Counter: Y (interrupt service routine)
2. Stack Pointer: T - M (pushed values)
3. General Registers: Saved on stack
4. Interrupt Service Routine executing

cards.title: Return from Interrupt
cards.back:
1. Restore PC, PSW, registers from stack
2. Resume user program at instruction N+1

cards.title: Two Key Questions
cards.back:
1. **Device Identification:**
2. How does processor determine which device issued interrupt?
3. Multiple I/O modules may interrupt
4. **Priority:**
5. If multiple interrupts occur, which to process first?
6. Need priority system

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: Separate interrupt line for each I/O module.

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. Most straightforward approach
2. Processor knows device from interrupt line
3. **Problem:** Limited number of interrupt lines
4. Even with multiple lines, each line may have multiple modules

cards.title: Use
cards.back: Simple systems, few devices

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: Interrupt acknowledge line daisy-chained through modules.

cards.title: Process
cards.back:
1. Processor detects interrupt
2. Processor responds on interrupt acknowledge line
3. Signal passes through daisy chain
4. First requesting module responds
5. Module places **vector** (address/identifier) on data lines
6. Processor uses vector to identify device

cards.title: Vector
cards.back:
1. Address of I/O module or unique identifier
2. **Vectored interrupt:** Processor uses vector as pointer to service routine
3. Avoids need for general interrupt service routine first

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. Automatic device identification
2. Fast (hardware-based)
3. Vectored interrupts efficient

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. Fixed priority (order in chain)
2. More complex hardware

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: I/O module must gain control of bus before raising interrupt.

cards.title: Process
cards.back:
1. I/O module requests bus control
2. Gains bus control
3. Raises interrupt request line
4. Processor detects interrupt
5. Processor responds on interrupt acknowledge
6. Requesting module places vector on data lines

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. Flexible priority (bus arbitration)
2. Vectored interrupts
3. Works with bus-based systems

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. Requires bus arbitration
2. More complex

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: Processor branches to interrupt service routine that polls each I/O module.

cards.title: Process
cards.back:
1. Processor detects interrupt
2. Branches to general interrupt service routine
3. Routine polls each I/O module
4. Determines which module caused interrupt
5. Branches to specific device service routine

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. Simple hardware
2. Flexible (software-controlled)
3. No special hardware needed

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **Time consuming:** Must check each module
2. Slower than hardware methods
3. Higher interrupt latency

cards.title: Use
cards.back: Systems with many devices, when hardware cost is concern

cards.title: Problem
cards.back: Multiple interrupts may occur simultaneously.

cards.title: Solutions
cards.back:
1. **Fixed Priority:**
2. Each device has fixed priority
3. Higher priority interrupts lower priority
4. Simple but inflexible
5. **Programmable Priority:**
6. Priority can be changed
7. More flexible
8. Requires priority controller
9. **Nested Interrupts:**
10. Higher priority can interrupt lower priority
11. Requires interrupt masking
12. More complex

cards.title: Interrupt Masking
cards.back:
1. Processor can disable interrupts
2. Critical sections protected
3. Interrupt enable/disable flags

cards.title: Drawbacks of Programmed and Interrupt-Driven I/O
cards.front: Drawbacks of Programmed and Interrupt-Driven I/O
cards.back:
1. **Transfer Rate Limited:**
2. Limited by speed processor can test and service device
3. Processor bottleneck
4. **Processor Tied Up:**
5. Processor involved in managing transfer
6. Multiple instructions per I/O transfer
7. Wastes processor cycles

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: **Direct Memory Access (DMA)** for large data volumes.

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: I/O module transfers data directly to/from memory without processor involvement.

cards.title: Key Points
cards.back:
1. Processor only involved at **start and end**
2. DMA controller handles transfer
3. Data bypasses processor
4. Very efficient for large transfers

cards.title: Components
cards.back:
1. **Data Count Register:**
2. Number of bytes/words to transfer
3. Decremented during transfer
4. Interrupts when reaches zero
5. **Data Register:**
6. Temporary data storage
7. For some DMA configurations
8. **Address Register:**
9. Memory address for transfer
10. Incremented during transfer
11. **Control Logic:**
12. Manages DMA operation
13. Handles bus requests
14. Coordinates transfer

cards.title: Signals
cards.back:
1. **Request to DMA:** Device requests DMA transfer
2. **Acknowledge from DMA:** DMA acknowledges request
3. **Read/Write:** Control signals
4. **Interrupt:** Signal completion

cards.title: Process
cards.back:
1. **Initialization (Processor):**
2. Processor sets up DMA:
3. Starting memory address
4. Number of bytes to transfer
5. Direction (read/write)
6. Processor issues DMA command
7. **Transfer (DMA Controller):**
8. DMA controller requests bus
9. Gains bus control
10. Transfers data directly:
11. Read from I/O device
12. Write to memory (or vice versa)
13. Increments address, decrements count
14. Continues until complete
15. **Completion (DMA Controller):**
16. DMA controller interrupts processor
17. Signals completion
18. Processor checks status

cards.title: Key
cards.back: Processor free during entire transfer!

cards.title: DMA Breakpoints
cards.back:
1. Can interrupt during instruction cycle
2. Typically between:
3. Instruction fetch and decode
4. Operand fetch and execute
5. Execute and store result

cards.title: Interrupt Breakpoints
cards.back:
1. Typically only between instructions
2. Must complete current instruction

cards.title: DMA More Flexible
cards.back:
1. Can interrupt during instruction execution
2. Steals bus cycles
3. Processor may need to wait for DMA

cards.title: Structure
cards.back: Processor ──┐ ├── System Bus ── Memory DMA ────────┘ I/O ────────┘

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. DMA on system bus
2. Competes with processor for bus
3. Bus arbitration needed
4. Simple but may cause contention

cards.title: Structure
cards.back: Processor ──┐ ├── System Bus ── Memory DMA+I/O ────┘

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. DMA integrated with I/O module
2. Still on system bus
3. More efficient (no separate DMA module)
4. Common configuration

cards.title: Structure
cards.back: Processor ── System Bus ── Memory DMA Controller I/O Bus ── I/O ── I/O ── I/O

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. Separate I/O bus
2. DMA controller bridges buses
3. Reduces system bus load
4. More complex but better performance

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: Data does **not** pass through DMA chip.

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. DMA only between I/O port and memory
2. **Not** between two I/O ports
3. **Not** between two memory locations
4. Data flows directly: I/O ↔ Memory

cards.title: Memory-to-Memory
cards.back:
1. Can do via register
2. Less efficient
3. Requires two transfers

cards.title: Example: Intel 8237
cards.back:
1. Contains four DMA channels
2. Each channel programmed independently
3. Any one channel active at a time
4. Fly-by operation

cards.title: Signals
cards.back:
1. **DREQ:** DMA request (from device)
2. **HRQ:** Hold request (to processor)
3. **HLDA:** Hold acknowledge (from processor)
4. **DACK:** DMA acknowledge (to device)

cards.title: Control Bus Signals
cards.back:
1. **IOR:** I/O read
2. **IOW:** I/O write
3. **MEMR:** Memory read
4. **MEMW:** Memory write

cards.title: Operation
cards.back:
1. Device requests DMA (DREQ)
2. DMA requests bus (HRQ)
3. Processor acknowledges (HLDA)
4. DMA transfers data using control signals
5. DMA completes, releases bus

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Manage multiple interrupt sources.

cards.title: Features
cards.back:
1. **8 interrupt request lines (IR0-IR7)**
2. Priority management
3. Interrupt vector generation
4. Cascading support

cards.title: Cascading
cards.back:
1. Multiple PICs can be cascaded
2. Master PIC connects to processor
3. Slave PICs connect to master
4. Example: 1 master + 3 slaves = 32 interrupt lines

cards.title: Configuration
cards.back: Master 82C59A ── Processor (INTR) ├── IR0-IR7 (8 devices) ├── Slave 82C59A (via IR) │ └── IR0-IR7 (8 devices) ├── Slave 82C59A (via IR) │ └── IR0-IR7 (8 devices) └── Slave 82C59A (via IR) └── IR0-IR7 (8 devices)

cards.title: Total
cards.back: Up to 64 interrupt sources (with cascading)

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Interface to parallel I/O devices.

cards.title: Features
cards.back:
1. **Three 8-bit ports:** Port A, Port B, Port C
2. **Port C split:** Upper (PC7-PC4) and Lower (PC3-PC0)
3. **Multiple modes:** Input, output, bidirectional
4. **Handshaking:** Control signals for device communication

cards.title: Ports
cards.back:
1. **Port A:** 8-bit I/O port (Group A)
2. **Port B:** 8-bit I/O port (Group B)
3. **Port C:** 8-bit I/O port or control signals

cards.title: Modes
cards.back:
1. **Mode 0:** Basic input/output
2. **Mode 1:** Handshaking I/O
3. **Mode 2:** Bidirectional bus

cards.title: Applications
cards.back:
1. Keyboard interfaces
2. Display interfaces
3. Parallel printer interfaces
4. General-purpose I/O
5. Port A: Keyboard input
6. Port B: Display output
7. Port C: Control signals (data ready, acknowledge)

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Widely used for peripheral connections.

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:

cards.title: Question
cards.back: System has 16-bit address bus, uses memory-mapped I/O. If 48 KB memory, how many I/O addresses available?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: Total address space: 2^16 = 64 KB Memory: 48 KB = 48,000 bytes I/O addresses: 64 KB - 48 KB = 16 KB = 16,384 addresses

cards.title: Answer
cards.back: 16,384 I/O addresses

cards.title: Question
cards.back: DMA transfers 64 KB block. Memory access time 100 ns, I/O device rate 10 MB/s. How long does transfer take?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: Data size: 64 KB = 65,536 bytes I/O device rate: 10 MB/s = 10,000,000 bytes/s Transfer time = 65,536 / 10,000,000 = 0.0065536 s = 6.55 ms

cards.title: Answer
cards.back: 6.55 ms (CPU free during this time)

cards.title: Question
cards.back: Interrupt service routine takes 50 cycles. System has 1000 interrupts/second. What is interrupt overhead?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: Interrupts per second: 1000 Cycles per interrupt: 50 Total cycles per second: 1000 × 50 = 50,000 cycles If CPU runs at 1 GHz (1,000,000,000 cycles/s): Overhead = 50,000 / 1,000,000,000 = 0.00005 = 0.005%

cards.title: Answer
cards.back: 0.005% CPU overhead

cards.title: Question
cards.back: Device transfers 1 byte every 10 ms. Programmed I/O: CPU checks every 1 μs. Interrupt-driven: 100 cycle overhead per interrupt. Which is more efficient?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back:
1. Checks every 1 μs
2. 10 ms = 10,000 μs
3. Number of checks: 10,000
4. Wastes 10,000 checks
5. One interrupt per byte
6. 100 cycles overhead
7. CPU free for 10 ms - interrupt time
8. Much more efficient

allCards.title: Problem
allCards.back: Why not connect peripherals directly to system bus?

allCards.title: Reasons
allCards.back:
1. **Wide Variety of Peripherals:**
2. Different methods of operation
3. Different data formats
4. Different speeds
5. **Impractical** to incorporate control logic within processor

8. Impractical to use high-speed system bus directly
9. Would waste bus bandwidth
10. **Some Peripherals Faster:**
11. Some devices faster than memory/processor
12. Mismatch leads to inefficiencies if not managed
13. **Data Format Differences:**
14. Peripherals use different data formats
15. Different word lengths
16. Need conversion/translation

allCards.title: Solution

allCards.back:
1. **Interface to Processor and Memory:**
2. Via system bus or central switch
3. Handles communication with CPU
4. Manages data transfer to/from memory
5. **Interface to Peripheral Devices:**
6. Via data links
7. Handles device-specific protocols
8. Manages device control and status

allCards.title: Result
allCards.back: I/O module acts as **translator** and **buffer** between system and peripherals.

allCards.back:

allCards.title: Key Difference
allCards.back: Role of processor in data transfer.

allCards.title: Definition
allCards.back: Processor directly controls I/O operation.

allCards.title: Process
allCards.back:
1. Processor executes I/O instruction
2. Issues command to I/O module
3. I/O module performs action
4. Sets status bits in status register
5. **Processor must periodically check status**
6. Processor waits until operation complete

allCards.title: Key Characteristic
allCards.back: **I/O module does NOT interrupt processor.**

allCards.title: Processor Responsibility
allCards.back:
1. Must check status repeatedly
2. Waits for I/O completion
3. Cannot do other work while waiting

allCards.title: Four Types of I/O Commands
allCards.back:
1. **Control:**
2. Activate peripheral
3. Tell device what to do
4. Example: Start printer, seek disk track
5. **Test:**
6. Test status conditions
7. Check I/O module and peripheral status
8. Example: Check if device ready, check for errors
9. **Read:**
10. I/O module obtains data from peripheral
11. Places data in internal buffer
12. Processor reads from buffer
13. **Write:**
14. I/O module takes data from data bus
15. Transmits data to peripheral
16. Processor writes to I/O module

allCards.title: Input of Block of Data
allCards.back:
1. Issue Read command to I/O module
2. Read status of I/O module
3. Check if ready
4. If not ready: Loop back to step 2
5. If ready: Continue
6. Read word from I/O module
7. Write word into memory
8. Check if done
9. If not done: Go to step 1 (next word)
10. If done: Next instruction

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **CPU waits:** Processor tied up during I/O
2. **Polling:** Must check status repeatedly
3. **Inefficient:** Wastes processor time
4. **Simple:** Easy to implement

allCards.title: Drawbacks
allCards.back:
1. Processor cannot do other work
2. Wastes CPU cycles checking status
3. Slow for slow devices

allCards.title: Definition
allCards.back: I/O module interrupts processor when ready.

allCards.title: Process
allCards.back:
1. Processor issues I/O command
2. **Processor continues executing other instructions**
3. I/O module works on I/O operation
4. When ready, I/O module **interrupts processor**
5. Processor handles interrupt
6. Executes data transfer
7. Resumes former processing

allCards.title: Key Advantage
allCards.back: **Processor can do other work while waiting.**

allCards.title: Input of Block of Data
allCards.back:
1. Issue Read command to I/O module
2. Do something else (other instructions)
3. Interrupt occurs (I/O module ready)
4. Read status of I/O module
5. Check for error condition
6. Read word from I/O module
7. Write word into memory
8. Check if done
9. If not done: Go to step 1
10. If done: Return to interrupted program

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **CPU not waiting:** Can do other work
2. **Asynchronous:** I/O happens in background
3. **Efficient:** Better CPU utilization
4. **More complex:** Requires interrupt handling

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. Better CPU utilization
2. Can handle multiple I/O operations
3. More responsive system

allCards.title: Drawbacks
allCards.back:
1. Still involves processor in each transfer
2. Interrupt overhead
3. More complex than programmed I/O

allCards.title: Definition
allCards.back: I/O module and memory exchange data directly without processor involvement.

allCards.title: Process
allCards.back:
1. Processor issues block read command to DMA module
2. **Processor continues executing other instructions**
3. DMA module transfers entire block directly to/from memory
4. DMA module interrupts processor when complete

allCards.title: Key Advantage
allCards.back: **Processor only involved at start and end.**

allCards.title: Input of Block of Data
allCards.back:

4. Interrupt occurs (DMA complete)
5. Read status of DMA module
6. Check for error condition

allCards.back:

2. **Direct transfer:** I/O to memory, bypassing CPU
3. **Very efficient:** Best for large transfers
4. **Most complex:** Requires DMA controller

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:

2. **High throughput:** Can transfer large blocks
3. **Best for bulk data:** Disk, network transfers

allCards.title: Drawbacks
allCards.back:
1. Most complex implementation
2. Requires DMA controller hardware
3. Bus arbitration needed

allCards.back:

allCards.back:

allCards.back:

4. Flexible addressing

allCards.back:

2. Memory and I/O compete for addresses

4. Restore old PSW and PC

allCards.title: Result
allCards.back: Processor loads new PC value based on interrupt, executes interrupt service routine, then returns.

allCards.title: Before Interrupt
allCards.back:
1. Program Counter: N
2. Stack Pointer: T
3. General Registers: Various values
4. User's Program executing

allCards.title: After Interrupt
allCards.back:
1. Program Counter: Y (interrupt service routine)
2. Stack Pointer: T - M (pushed values)
3. General Registers: Saved on stack
4. Interrupt Service Routine executing

allCards.title: Return from Interrupt
allCards.back:
1. Restore PC, PSW, registers from stack
2. Resume user program at instruction N+1

allCards.title: Two Key Questions
allCards.back:
1. **Device Identification:**
2. How does processor determine which device issued interrupt?
3. Multiple I/O modules may interrupt

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: Separate interrupt line for each I/O module.

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. Most straightforward approach
2. Processor knows device from interrupt line
3. **Problem:** Limited number of interrupt lines
4. Even with multiple lines, each line may have multiple modules

allCards.title: Use
allCards.back: Simple systems, few devices

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: Interrupt acknowledge line daisy-chained through modules.

allCards.title: Process
allCards.back:
1. Processor detects interrupt
2. Processor responds on interrupt acknowledge line
3. Signal passes through daisy chain
4. First requesting module responds
5. Module places **vector** (address/identifier) on data lines
6. Processor uses vector to identify device

allCards.title: Vector
allCards.back:
1. Address of I/O module or unique identifier
2. **Vectored interrupt:** Processor uses vector as pointer to service routine
3. Avoids need for general interrupt service routine first

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. Automatic device identification
2. Fast (hardware-based)
3. Vectored interrupts efficient

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. Fixed priority (order in chain)
2. More complex hardware

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: I/O module must gain control of bus before raising interrupt.

allCards.title: Process
allCards.back:
1. I/O module requests bus control
2. Gains bus control
3. Raises interrupt request line
4. Processor detects interrupt
5. Processor responds on interrupt acknowledge
6. Requesting module places vector on data lines

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. Flexible priority (bus arbitration)
2. Vectored interrupts
3. Works with bus-based systems

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. Requires bus arbitration
2. More complex

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: Processor branches to interrupt service routine that polls each I/O module.

allCards.title: Process
allCards.back:
1. Processor detects interrupt
2. Branches to general interrupt service routine
3. Routine polls each I/O module
4. Determines which module caused interrupt
5. Branches to specific device service routine

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. Simple hardware
2. Flexible (software-controlled)
3. No special hardware needed

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. **Time consuming:** Must check each module
2. Slower than hardware methods
3. Higher interrupt latency

allCards.title: Use
allCards.back: Systems with many devices, when hardware cost is concern

allCards.title: Problem
allCards.back: Multiple interrupts may occur simultaneously.

allCards.title: Solutions
allCards.back:
1. **Fixed Priority:**
2. Each device has fixed priority
3. Higher priority interrupts lower priority
4. Simple but inflexible
5. **Programmable Priority:**
6. Priority can be changed
7. More flexible
8. Requires priority controller
9. **Nested Interrupts:**
10. Higher priority can interrupt lower priority
11. Requires interrupt masking
12. More complex

allCards.title: Interrupt Masking
allCards.back:
1. Processor can disable interrupts
2. Critical sections protected
3. Interrupt enable/disable flags

allCards.title: Drawbacks of Programmed and Interrupt-Driven I/O
allCards.front: Drawbacks of Programmed and Interrupt-Driven I/O
allCards.back:
1. **Transfer Rate Limited:**
2. Limited by speed processor can test and service device
3. Processor bottleneck
4. **Processor Tied Up:**
5. Processor involved in managing transfer
6. Multiple instructions per I/O transfer
7. Wastes processor cycles

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: **Direct Memory Access (DMA)** for large data volumes.

allCards.title: Definition
allCards.back: I/O module transfers data directly to/from memory without processor involvement.

allCards.title: Key Points
allCards.back:
1. Processor only involved at **start and end**
2. DMA controller handles transfer
3. Data bypasses processor
4. Very efficient for large transfers

allCards.title: Components
allCards.back:
1. **Data Count Register:**
2. Number of bytes/words to transfer
3. Decremented during transfer
4. Interrupts when reaches zero
5. **Data Register:**
6. Temporary data storage
7. For some DMA configurations
8. **Address Register:**
9. Memory address for transfer
10. Incremented during transfer
11. **Control Logic:**
12. Manages DMA operation
13. Handles bus requests
14. Coordinates transfer

allCards.title: Signals
allCards.back:
1. **Request to DMA:** Device requests DMA transfer
2. **Acknowledge from DMA:** DMA acknowledges request
3. **Read/Write:** Control signals
4. **Interrupt:** Signal completion

allCards.title: Process
allCards.back:
1. **Initialization (Processor):**
2. Processor sets up DMA:
3. Starting memory address
4. Number of bytes to transfer
5. Direction (read/write)
6. Processor issues DMA command
7. **Transfer (DMA Controller):**
8. DMA controller requests bus
9. Gains bus control
10. Transfers data directly:
11. Read from I/O device
12. Write to memory (or vice versa)
13. Increments address, decrements count
14. Continues until complete
15. **Completion (DMA Controller):**
16. DMA controller interrupts processor
17. Signals completion
18. Processor checks status

allCards.title: Key
allCards.back: Processor free during entire transfer!

allCards.title: DMA Breakpoints
allCards.back:
1. Can interrupt during instruction cycle
2. Typically between:
3. Instruction fetch and decode
4. Operand fetch and execute
5. Execute and store result

allCards.title: Interrupt Breakpoints
allCards.back:
1. Typically only between instructions
2. Must complete current instruction

allCards.title: DMA More Flexible
allCards.back:

2. Steals bus cycles
3. Processor may need to wait for DMA

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: Data does **not** pass through DMA chip.

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:

2. **Not** between two I/O ports
3. **Not** between two memory locations

allCards.back:

allCards.back:

allCards.back:

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: System has 16-bit address bus, uses memory-mapped I/O. If 48 KB memory, how many I/O addresses available?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: Total address space: 2^16 = 64 KB Memory: 48 KB = 48,000 bytes I/O addresses: 64 KB - 48 KB = 16 KB = 16,384 addresses

allCards.title: Answer
allCards.back: 16,384 I/O addresses

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: DMA transfers 64 KB block. Memory access time 100 ns, I/O device rate 10 MB/s. How long does transfer take?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: Data size: 64 KB = 65,536 bytes I/O device rate: 10 MB/s = 10,000,000 bytes/s Transfer time = 65,536 / 10,000,000 = 0.0065536 s = 6.55 ms

allCards.title: Answer
allCards.back: 6.55 ms (CPU free during this time)

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: Interrupt service routine takes 50 cycles. System has 1000 interrupts/second. What is interrupt overhead?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: Interrupts per second: 1000 Cycles per interrupt: 50 Total cycles per second: 1000 × 50 = 50,000 cycles If CPU runs at 1 GHz (1,000,000,000 cycles/s): Overhead = 50,000 / 1,000,000,000 = 0.00005 = 0.005%

allCards.title: Answer
allCards.back: 0.005% CPU overhead

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: Device transfers 1 byte every 10 ms. Programmed I/O: CPU checks every 1 μs. Interrupt-driven: 100 cycle overhead per interrupt. Which is more efficient?

allCards.title: Solution

1. Checks every 1 μs
2. 10 ms = 10,000 μs
3. Number of checks: 10,000
4. Wastes 10,000 checks
5. One interrupt per byte
6. 100 cycles overhead
7. CPU free for 10 ms - interrupt time
8. Much more efficient
